segment.source: Sysprep (System Preparation) Overview
segment.target: Sysprep (System Preparation) Overview

segment.source: Sysprep (System Preparation) Overview
segment.target: Sysprep (System Preparation) Overview

segment.source: Sysprep (System Preparation) Overview
segment.target: Sysprep (System Preparation) Overview

segment.source: Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.

segment.source: Sysprep (System Preparation) prepares a Windows installation (Windows client and Windows Server) for imaging, allowing you to capture a customized installation.
segment.target: Sysprep (System Preparation) prepares a Windows installation (Windows client and Windows Server) for imaging, allowing you to capture a customized installation.

segment.source: Sysprep removes PC-specific information from a Windows installation, "generalizing" the installation so it can be installed on different PCs.
segment.target: Sysprep removes PC-specific information from a Windows installation, "generalizing" the installation so it can be installed on different PCs.

segment.source: With Sysprep you can configure the PC to boot to audit mode, where you can make additional changes or updates to your image.
segment.target: With Sysprep you can configure the PC to boot to audit mode, where you can make additional changes or updates to your image.

segment.source: Or, you can configure Windows to boot to the Out-of-Box Experience (OOBE).
segment.target: Or, you can configure Windows to boot to the Out-of-Box Experience (OOBE).

segment.source: Sysprep is part of the Windows image, and is used during audit mode.
segment.target: Sysprep is part of the Windows image, and is used during audit mode.

segment.source: Feature description
segment.target: Feature description

segment.source: Sysprep provides the following features:
segment.target: Sysprep provides the following features:

segment.source: Removes PC-specific information from the Windows image, including the PC’s security identifier (SID).
segment.target: Removes PC-specific information from the Windows image, including the PC’s security identifier (SID).

segment.source: This allows you to capture the image and apply it to other PCs.
segment.target: This allows you to capture the image and apply it to other PCs.

segment.source: This is known as generalizing the PC.
segment.target: This is known as generalizing the PC.

segment.source: Uninstalls PC-specific drivers from the Windows image.
segment.target: Uninstalls PC-specific drivers from the Windows image.

segment.source: Prepares the PC for delivery to a customer by setting the PC to boot to OOBE.
segment.target: Prepares the PC for delivery to a customer by setting the PC to boot to OOBE.

segment.source: Allows you to add answer file (unattend) settings to an existing installation.
segment.target: Allows you to add answer file (unattend) settings to an existing installation.

segment.source: Practical applications
segment.target: Practical applications

segment.source: Sysprep helps you solve business goals such as:
segment.target: Sysprep helps you solve business goals such as:

segment.source: Helps you manage multiple PCs by creating a generic image that can be used across multiple hardware designs.
segment.target: Helps you manage multiple PCs by creating a generic image that can be used across multiple hardware designs.

segment.source: Deploy PCs by capturing and deploying images with unique security identifiers.
segment.target: Deploy PCs by capturing and deploying images with unique security identifiers.

segment.source: Fine-tune setup of individual PCs by adding apps, languages, or drivers in audit mode.
segment.target: Fine-tune setup of individual PCs by adding apps, languages, or drivers in audit mode.

segment.source: For more information, see Audit Mode Overview.
segment.target: For more information, see Audit Mode Overview.

segment.source: Provide more reliable PCs by testing in audit mode before delivering them to customers.
segment.target: Provide more reliable PCs by testing in audit mode before delivering them to customers.

segment.source: New and changed functionality
segment.target: New and changed functionality

segment.source: Beginning with Windows 10, version 1607, Sysprep can be used to prepare an image that has been upgraded.
segment.target: Beginning with Windows 10, version 1607, Sysprep can be used to prepare an image that has been upgraded.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: You can start with a computer that runs Windows 10, version 1507.
segment.target: You can start with a computer that runs Windows 10, version 1507.

segment.source: Upgrade the computer to run Windows 10, version 1607.
segment.target: Upgrade the computer to run Windows 10, version 1607.

segment.source: Run Sysprep generalize on the upgraded image, re-capture the updated image, and deploy the image to new devices.
segment.target: Run Sysprep generalize on the upgraded image, re-capture the updated image, and deploy the image to new devices.

segment.source: This process allows enterprises to efficiently and continuously roll out up-to-date Windows 10 deployment images.
segment.target: This process allows enterprises to efficiently and continuously roll out up-to-date Windows 10 deployment images.

segment.source: Beginning with Windows 8.1, the Sysprep user interface is deprecated.
segment.target: Beginning with Windows 8.1, the Sysprep user interface is deprecated.

segment.source: The Sysprep UI will continue to be supported in this release however it may be removed in a future release.
segment.target: The Sysprep UI will continue to be supported in this release however it may be removed in a future release.

segment.source: We recommend that you update your deployment workflow to use Sysprep from the command line.
segment.target: We recommend that you update your deployment workflow to use Sysprep from the command line.

segment.source: For more information, see Sysprep Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information, see Sysprep Command-Line Options.

segment.source: Dependencies
segment.target: Dependencies

segment.source: You must run Windows Setup before you use Sysprep.
segment.target: You must run Windows Setup before you use Sysprep.

segment.source: You need a tool to capture an image of the installation, such as DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows or other disk-imaging software.
segment.target: You need a tool to capture an image of the installation, such as DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows or other disk-imaging software.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: When you copy Windows images between PCs, the reference and destination PCs may not have to have compatible hardware abstraction layers (HALs).
segment.target: When you copy Windows images between PCs, the reference and destination PCs may not have to have compatible hardware abstraction layers (HALs).

segment.source: The /detecthal option in the Boot Configuration Data (BCD) enables a system that has already run Sysprep to install the correct HAL.
segment.target: The /detecthal option in the Boot Configuration Data (BCD) enables a system that has already run Sysprep to install the correct HAL.

segment.source: Limitations
segment.target: Limitations

segment.source: Sysprep has the following limitations:
segment.target: Sysprep has the following limitations:

segment.source: The security identifier (SID) is only replaced on the operating system volume when you execute Sysprep.
segment.target: The security identifier (SID) is only replaced on the operating system volume when you execute Sysprep.

segment.source: If a single PC has multiple operating systems, you must run Sysprep on each image individually.
segment.target: If a single PC has multiple operating systems, you must run Sysprep on each image individually.

segment.source: In some cases, customized applications that you install before you recapture the Windows image may require a consistent drive letter.
segment.target: In some cases, customized applications that you install before you recapture the Windows image may require a consistent drive letter.

segment.source: Some applications store paths that include the system's drive letter.
segment.target: Some applications store paths that include the system's drive letter.

segment.source: Uninstallation, servicing, and repair scenarios may not function correctly if the system's drive letter does not match the drive letter that the application specifies.
segment.target: Uninstallation, servicing, and repair scenarios may not function correctly if the system's drive letter does not match the drive letter that the application specifies.

segment.source: The Plug and Play devices on the reference and destination PCs do not have to be from the same manufacturer.
segment.target: The Plug and Play devices on the reference and destination PCs do not have to be from the same manufacturer.

segment.source: These devices include modems, sound cards, network adapters, and video cards.
segment.target: These devices include modems, sound cards, network adapters, and video cards.

segment.source: However, the installation must include the drivers for these devices.
segment.target: However, the installation must include the drivers for these devices.

segment.source: Not all server roles support Sysprep.
segment.target: Not all server roles support Sysprep.

segment.source: If you generalize a Windows Server installation that has specific server roles configured, those server roles may not continue to function after the imaging and deployment process.
segment.target: If you generalize a Windows Server installation that has specific server roles configured, those server roles may not continue to function after the imaging and deployment process.

segment.source: For more information, see Sysprep Support for Server Roles.
segment.target: For more information, see Sysprep Support for Server Roles.

segment.source: If you run Sysprep on an NTFS file system partition that contains encrypted files or folders, the data in those folders becomes completely unreadable and unrecoverable.
segment.target: If you run Sysprep on an NTFS file system partition that contains encrypted files or folders, the data in those folders becomes completely unreadable and unrecoverable.

segment.source: The Sysprep tool runs only if the PC is a member of a workgroup, not a domain.
segment.target: The Sysprep tool runs only if the PC is a member of a workgroup, not a domain.

segment.source: If the PC is joined to a domain, Sysprep removes the PC from the domain.
segment.target: If the PC is joined to a domain, Sysprep removes the PC from the domain.

segment.source: If a PC is joined to a domain, and the Group Policy of that domain assigns a strong account password policy to the PC, all user accounts will require strong passwords.
segment.target: If a PC is joined to a domain, and the Group Policy of that domain assigns a strong account password policy to the PC, all user accounts will require strong passwords.

segment.source: Running Sysprep or OOBE does not remove the strong password policy.
segment.target: Running Sysprep or OOBE does not remove the strong password policy.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: If you do not assign a strong password to a user account before you run Sysprep or OOBE, you may not be able to log on to the PC.
segment.target: If you do not assign a strong password to a user account before you run Sysprep or OOBE, you may not be able to log on to the PC.

segment.source: We recommend that you always use strong passwords for your user accounts.
segment.target: We recommend that you always use strong passwords for your user accounts.

segment.source: Unsupported Scenarios
segment.target: Unsupported Scenarios

segment.source: The following scenarios are not supported:
segment.target: The following scenarios are not supported:

segment.source: Moving or copying a Windows image to a different PC without generalizing the PC is not supported.
segment.target: Moving or copying a Windows image to a different PC without generalizing the PC is not supported.

segment.source: Using a different version of the Sysprep tool to configure an image is not supported.
segment.target: Using a different version of the Sysprep tool to configure an image is not supported.

segment.source: You must use only the version of the Sysprep tool that is installed with the Windows image that you intend to configure.
segment.target: You must use only the version of the Sysprep tool that is installed with the Windows image that you intend to configure.

segment.source: Sysprep is installed with every version of Windows.
segment.target: Sysprep is installed with every version of Windows.

segment.source: You must always run Sysprep from the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory.
segment.target: You must always run Sysprep from the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory.

segment.source: If you are using a version of Windows earlier than Windows 10, Version 1607, using the Sysprep tool on upgrade installation types, or to reconfigure an existing installation of Windows that has already been deployed is not supported.
segment.target: If you are using a version of Windows earlier than Windows 10, Version 1607, using the Sysprep tool on upgrade installation types, or to reconfigure an existing installation of Windows that has already been deployed is not supported.

segment.source: In this case, Sysprep must be used only to configure new installations of Windows.
segment.target: In this case, Sysprep must be used only to configure new installations of Windows.

segment.source: You can run Sysprep an unlimited number of times to build and configure your installation of Windows.
segment.target: You can run Sysprep an unlimited number of times to build and configure your installation of Windows.

segment.source: Automating Sysprep by using a Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentRunSynchronous command is not supported.
segment.target: Automating Sysprep by using a Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentRunSynchronous command is not supported.

segment.source: However, you can use the Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentGeneralize setting to prepare the PC for imaging after installation.
segment.target: However, you can use the Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentGeneralize setting to prepare the PC for imaging after installation.

segment.source: Running VM mode outside a virtual machine (VM) is unsupported.
segment.target: Running VM mode outside a virtual machine (VM) is unsupported.

segment.source: You cannot use VM mode to prepare a VHD for deployment to any PC.
segment.target: You cannot use VM mode to prepare a VHD for deployment to any PC.

segment.source: Sysprep cannot be run under the context of a System account.
segment.target: Sysprep cannot be run under the context of a System account.

segment.source: Running Sysprep under the context of System account by using Task Scheduler or PSExec, for example, is not supported.
segment.target: Running Sysprep under the context of System account by using Task Scheduler or PSExec, for example, is not supported.

segment.target: See also

segment.target: The following table contains links to resources related to this scenario.
